article_title: Shoemaking Gets a Foot in the Door in the U.S.
article_text:
JEFFERSON CITY, Tenn.—Reviving the U.S. shoe industry is proving trickier than Loretta Lee imagined.

On a recent visit to her new work-boot factory here, Ms. Lee walked along a row of sewing machines where newly hired workers in orange baseball caps struggled to cut and stitch leather. Dressed elegantly in shiny pumps and a sheath dress, Ms. Lee...

twitter.description: A new factory in Tennessee to make work boots is a glimmer of hope for the U.S. footwear industry. U.S.-made footwear accounts for only about 2% of the market, with the rest coming from imports.
twitter.creator: @jamesrhagerty

image.alt: Only about 2% of the footwear sold in the U.S. is made in America. That could change

twitter.title: Shoemaking Gets a Foot in the Door in the U.S.

article_summary:
Dressed elegantly in shiny pumps and a sheath dress, Ms. Lee...
JEFFERSON CITY, Tenn.—Reviving the U.S. shoe industry is proving trickier than Loretta Lee imagined.
On a recent visit to her new work-boot factory here, Ms. Lee walked along a row of sewing machines where newly hired workers in orange baseball caps struggled to cut and stitch leather.
